org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON.
SAM PLASTINO vs. HENRY M. WHITE, United States Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, Washington. }} PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
TO THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON:
The petition of Sam Plastino respectfully alleges:

That your petitioner is, and ever since the month of June, 1697, has been, continuously a resident and actual inhabitant of the United States of America; that he is now an inhabitant and resident of the city of Spokane, Washington; that your petitioner is now of the age of thirty years; that he wes brought to the United States at the age of about ten years by his parents; that his father, Michele Plastino, duly made declaration of intention to become a citizen of the United States in the year 1900; that thereafter, and before taking out his final citizenship papers, the said Michele Plastino died; that your petitioner, in mistaken belief that he, upon attaining the age of twenty-one years, became a citizen of the United States and entitled to all the rights and privileges of such, failed to ap-
ply for citizenship in the United States until the month of March, 1911, when he duly made, in the United States District Court of Eastern District of Washington, his declaration of intention to become a citizen of the United States.
II.

That your petitioner is now actually imprisoned and restrained of his liberty, and detained at seattle, Washington, by color of the au- thority of the United States, in the custody of Henry M. White, Esquire, United States Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, Washington, within said Western District of Washington.
III.

That the sole claim or authority by virtue of which the said Henry M. White, Commissioner as aforesaid, so restrains and detains your petitioner, is a certain warrant in writing, a copy of which is hereto an- nexed. marked "Exhibit A," issued by Benjamin S. Cable, Esquire, Acting Secretary of Commerce and Labor, and a certain order in writing issued by Dan'l J. Keefe. Commissioner General, Department of Commerce and Labor, Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization, a copy of which is hereto an- nexed. marked "Exhibit B;" which warrants and orders are incorporated herein by reference and made a part hereof, with like effect as if herein set forth at length.

That said warrants were issued pursuant to a pretended order of deportation made by Benjamin S. Cable, Esquire, Acting Secretary of Commerce and Labor of the United States, upon alleged proofs said to have been submitted at a pretended hearing before Immigrant Inspector T. M. Fisher, alleged to have been held at Tacoma, Washington, in the year 1912.

That the pretended record of said hearing and the sole pre- tended proofs upon which said order of deportation was based are hereto
attached, marked "Exhibit C."
IV.

That at all times referred to in this petition, there was, and now is, in effect, the following rules of the United States Department of Commerce and Labor, Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization, relating to proceedings for the deportation of aliens:

Rule 22. Subdivision I. Officers shall make thorough investigation of all cases where they are credibly in- formed or have reason to believe that a specified alien in the United States is subject to arrest and deporta- tion on warrant.
Subdivision II. (a) The application must state facts bringing the alien within one or more of the classes sub- ject to deportation after entry.

Subdivision IV. (a) Upon receipt of a warrant of arrest, the alien shall be taken before the person or persons therein described and granted a hearing to enable him to show cause, if any there be, why he should not be deported.

(b) During the course of the hearing the alien shall be allowed to inspect the warrant of arrest and all the evidence on which it was issued; and at such stage thereof as the officer before whom the hearing is held shall deem proper, he shall be apprised that he may there- after be represented by counsel and shall be required then and there to state whether he desires counsel or waives the same, and his reply shall be entered on the record. If coun- sel be selected, he shall be permitted to be present during the further conduct of the hearing, to inspect and make a copy of the minutes of the hearing, so far as it has pro- ceeded, and to offer evidence to meet any evidence thereto- fore or thereafter presented by the Government. Objections and exceptions of counsel shall not be entered on the record, but may be dealt with in an accompanying brief. If during the hearing new facts are proved which constitute a reason additional to those stated in the warrant of arrest why the alien is in the country in violation of law, the alien's attention shall be directed to such facts and reason, and he shall be given an opportunity to show cause why he should not be deported therefor.
V.

Your petitioner alleges that no hearing was had before said T.M. Fisher, or at all, upon the charge that your petitioner had received, shared in, or derived benefit from the earnings of prostitutes, or upon the charge
that your petitioner is or was unlawfully within the United States and that he has been found receiving, sharing in, and deriving benefit from the earnings of prostitutes, or upon any charge of similar nature. Your petitioner further alleges that the only proceedings of any kind, form, or character, for the deportation of your petitioner, were the proceedings referred to in paragraph VI hereof. That no warrant or complaint charging your petitioner with having received, shared in, and derived benefit from the earnings of prostitutes, or charging him with being unlawfully within the United States in that he was found receiving, sharing in, and deriving benefit from the earnings of prostitutes, or charging him with any offence or act of similar nature or character was ever served upon or exhibited to your petitioner. That he was never informed that such a warrant had been issued or such a charge made against him in any form; that he never inspected and was never permitted or given opportunity to inspect any such warrant, if such warrant was ever issued; that he never inspected and never was permitted or given opportunity to inspect the evidence, if any was taken, or any part thereof, upon which such warrant, if issued, was issued; that your petitioner was never granted or offered a hearing or opportunity of any kind to show cause why he should not be deported; that he was never informed that any action or proceeding for his deportation was pending or that any inquiry was being made upon or out of which an order of deporta- tion might issue; that except as stated in paragraph VI hereofhe was not present at and had no notice of or op- portunity to be present at the pretended hearing before the said T. M. Fisher referred to in the Exhibit A hereto attached. That your petition- er was never apprised that he might be represented by counsel upon the hearing of such charge; that he was not represented by counsel at any hearing thereon; that neither your petitioner nor his counsel was permitted to, nor did your petitioner or his counsel inspect or make a copy of the

minutes or any part thereof, of any such hearing; that he wes not per- mitted to and did not offer evidence to meet any evidence presented by the Government, nor was he in any manner informed of the character of the evidence presented by the Government, or the names of any of the witnesses by whom said evidence was or would be given, or of the time or place when their testimony would be given; that he was not present at nor was he given notice or opportunity to be present at the examination of any witnesses or to cross-examine them or any of them.

That there was no evidence offered or submitted which proved or tended to prove the charge contained in the pretended warrant of arrest here- in or to sustain the findings upon which the said order of deportation was made
VI.

That the pretended evidence or testimony of your petitioner be- fore the said T. M. Fisher was given under the following circumstances, and not otherwise: That the aforesaid T.M. Fisher called upon your petitioner in the county jail of Pierce County, Washington, in the city of Tacoma, on or about the 26th day of January, 1912, and then and there stated to your petitioner that he, the said T.M. Fisher, desired to procure a statement from your petitioner; that the said T.M. Fisher or Charles E. Keagy did not then or thereafter, or at all, inform your petitioner of the purpose or ob- ject of said examination; that the said T.M. Fisher or Charles E. Keagy did not then or thereafter inform your petitioner that he was arrested under and by virtue of Department Warrant 53259/150, dated January 12, 1912, is- sued by the Acting Secretary of Commerce and Labor, in that he entered the United States in violation of the act of Congress approved February 20, 1917, amended by Act approved March 26, 1910, towit: That the said alien is unlawfully within the United States in that he has been found receiv- ing, sharing in or deriving benefit from the earnings of a prostitute or prostitutes; that this hearing is for the purpose of giving him an ample opportunity to show cause why he should not be deported to the country whence he came in conformity with law; nor did they or either of them make
any statement of similar import to your petitioner; nor did they or either of them inform your petitioner that the statements made by your petitioner upon said examination, or any part thereof, would or might be used againat him or that said examination was had in connection with or in relation to any warrant or charge that had been issued or made against him. That the said T.M. Fisher or Charles E. Keagy did not, upon said examination, or at all, state to your petitioner, "You have a right to be represented by coun- sel if you desire; or words of similar import; that your petitioner did not then, or at all, answer or say, "If my brother in Spokane will get a lawyer for me, I want a lawyer; if he will not, I do not care for any;" or words of similar import. That the said T.M. Fisher or Charles E. Keagy did not then, or at all, say to your petitioner, "Then, if your brother in Spokane does not see fit to retain a lawyer for you, do you waive your right to be represented by counsel?" or words of similar import. That your petitioner did not then, or at all, respond or say, "Yes;" or use any word or words of similar import. That the said T.M. Fisher or Charles E. Keagy did not then, or at all, say to your petitioner, "By your brother you mean Joe Plas- tino." or words of similar import. That your petitioner did not then, or at all, respond or say, "Yes, sir;" or words of similar import. That had your petitioner been informed of the nature and object of said proceedings and of his right to be represented by counsel, he would have procured coun- sel for that purpose.

That the pretended transcript of the examination of your peti- tioner set forth in Exhibit C did not, as originally written, contain said pretended questions or answers, or any of them, but that said pretended ques tions and each of them were written into the said pretended record of the examination of your petitioner after the same was ori- ginally transcribed, as more fully appears by the affidavit of John King, hereto attached (marked Exhibit D).
That your petitioner is informed by his brother, Joseph Plastino, (whose affidavit thereto is hereto attached, marked Exhibit E) and upon in-

formation and belief states the fact to be that the said T.M. Fisher did not, at any time or place, propound to the said Joseph Plastino the fol- lowing questions, or any questions of similar nature or import:

Q. BY INSPECTOR FISHER. (To Joe Plastino, brother of Sam Plastino). "Your brother, Sam Plastino, has been given a hearing to show his right to be, or remain, in the United States. He states that he wanted an attorney to represent him, provided you will furnish the same"?
That the said Joseph Plastino did not then, or at any time, give the following answer, or any answer of similar nature or import:
A. (BY JOE PLASTINO)
"I am through with him for good; I will have nothing to do with hiring an attorney for him."

That the said T.M. Fisher did not inform the said Joseph Plastino that deportation proceedings were pending against the said Sam Plastino; that the subject of the employment of counsel for the said Sam Plastino in said matter, or in any matter or proceeding of any kind and character, was not then, or at any other time, mentioned to the said Joseph Plastino in any manner or form by the said T.M. Fisher.
That your petitioner was never informed by the said T.M.Fisher or at all, and never heard of the pretended refusal of his brother, Joseph Plastino, to furnish him counsel in said proceeding.
VII.

That no action was taken by the said Department of Commerce and Labor or by the Bureau of Immigration, or by any officer or agent thereof, or at all, to execute said order or warrant of deportation or cause the warrant of deportation of your petitioner, until about the 15th day of July, 1916.

That the order of Dan'l J. Keefe, Commissioner General of the Department of Commerce and Labor (Exhibit B, hereto attached), directing that "execution of the warrant of deportation should be held in abeyance until such time as the alien is released from prison," was and is without
authority of law, and void.
VIII.

That your petitioner is now unlawfully held by the said Henry M. White, Commissioner as aforesaid, by virtue of said order and warrants and not otherwise; the said Henry M. White, Commissioner as aforesaid, is about to cause the deportation of your petitioner to the Kingdom of Italy, and will do so unless prevented from so doing by the order of this court.
IX.

That in said proceedings your petitioner was not given a fair or impartial trial, and the said proceedings and the said warrants and order of deportation were and are without legal right, authority, or jurisdiction of any kind, and are in violation of that clause of the fifth amendment of the Constitution of the United States providing that no person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property without due process of law, and are in violation of the provisions of the sixth amendment of the Constitution of the United States that in all criminal prosecutions the accused shall be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation, shall be confronted with the witnesses against him, and have the assistance of counsel for his defence; and that your petitioner's detention and imprisonment thereunder are in violation of the Constitution of the United States and in violation of the rights, privileges, and immunities thereunder.

WHEREFORE Your petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus may issue, directed to the said Henry M. White aforesaid, or to any of his deputies, requiring him or them to bring and have your petitioner before this court at a time to be by it determined, together with the true cause of his detention, to the end that due inquiry may be had in the premises and that this court may proceed in a summary way to determine the facts
of the case in that regard, and the legality of your petitioner's im- prisonment, restraint, detention, and deportation, and thereupon to dispose of your petitioner as law and justice require. And your peti- tioner will ever pray.
Tolman & King
Joseph Glasglow Attorneys for Petitioner.
Sam Plastino Petitioner.
STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF KING ))) SS.

SAM PLASTINO, being first duly sworn, on oath says: That he is the petitioner in the foregoing petition; that he has read said petition and knows the contents thereof, and that the same is true of his own knowledge except as to the matters therein stated to be on information and belief, and as to those matters he believes it to be true.
Sam Plastino
SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN TO Before me this 30th day of July, 1916.
Sam C. Griffin Notary Public for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle, Washington.
